Review Text: There are nice views of the tea plantation but they can be had for free from the side of any road in the region. Our half hour 200 rupee pp tour took about 10 minutes and our guide clearly didn’t want to be there. I also found the tea at the end to be weak. Not a highlight for the trip.

We were looking forward to seeing a working tea factory in action, learn about tea and enjoy a tasting to understand different varieties and qualities of tea. None of this actually happened as we were shown around an empty tea factory looking at machines and being told the absolute minimum by a bored and annoyed guide. After the tour we were given a cup of tea and encouraged to buy tea from the shop. Far too commercialise. If you want to learn about tea and enjoy a tea tasting go somewhere else, this was totally not worth the time or energy.

I was a bit disturbed that they call these factories plus staff housing "estates" when in reality its modem plantations. Please ask your guide for more info... they don't hide information about the setup of these "estates". All staff seem happy and at peace, grateful even, for the accommodations and the work. Please take the factory tour - very informative - from start to finish. You learn the entire tea process. The best part is learning how tea "tasters" from all over Sri Lanka have such a delicate palate they can identify any tea from any region by taste and smell. I love the sustainability museum at the end of the tour. It's nice to see that such hard work and production is done with the environment in mind.

Unfortunately the weather wasn't the best on the day. The gentleman who gave the tour seemed very passionate about the place, and provided some interesting facts. Not sure that I would have come here if I wasn't on a group tour, knowing the living and work  conditions of tea plantation tea pickers.  Though this place had many posters stating how they house and help their workers.

We really enjoyed the tour of this working factory. We did not appreciate the hard manual work required for tea picking and sorting thereafter. We have all resolved that we MUST pay more for our tea as the tea pickers don’t get paid enough- it seems less than US$10 per day. Shocking!

Of all the tea factories, this one felt most genuine, not a tourist trap at all! Totally recommended, interesting overview of a tea factory's ins and outs, set to a beautiful view, with a lovely cup of tea as a finale!

We were staying overnight in Nuwara Eliya and borrowed bikes to visit the Pedro tea factory. The ride up the hillside was tough but it was so beautiful to cycle the paths through the plantation we didn't mind. The tour itself lasts about 30 minutes and the smell of the fresh tea is intoxicating in the drying room. Our guide spoke perfect English and was happy to answer questions. After the tour we tasted some of the tea, which was delicious! Definitely worth a visit if you have a free morning.

Had a nice 20 minute tour round the factory (note: machinery operates only at night). The tea house could do with having a larger outside terrace to enjoy the plantation views whilst sampling the different teas. Also had a wander through the plantation for some good photo ops with/of the tea pickers.
Unfortunately our guide seemed really uninterested in showing us around and answering our questions. She did not even paid attention to us. Would not recommend!

Excursions to the factory goes every half an hour. (Till 16.30, as I remember) If you want to see working machines, you need to come in early mornings (may be not all days) But it’s not necessary to see  exactly working process. It’s interesting anyway. Guides speaks English, so all information is understandable. You could see old machines and know many interesting facts about tea manufacture. The smell of tea is amazing. And also you could walk among tea trees on tea plantations behind the factory. It’s very beautiful. You could see the process of picking tea leaves into special baskets. Working women could show you tea leaves and you could taste it. So also they suggest you to take a photo with them, but they also wants you to pay for photos. And it’s strange. Also you could but very good tea in a factory shop. In the shop you could ask about process of brewing tea. It’s a good gift.

We spent a couple of hours at the pedro tea factory We were guided by loshini who was very good at answering our questions and translated the information about how tea leaves were processed in english and Tamil as well. Highly recommended if you want an informative tour about tea leaves :)

You can visit wonderful tea gardens and taste tea. There are short tours in the factory where you can see the tea production step by step, and there is a free tea tasting at the end of the tour. There is also a sales office where you can buy gift tea.

Great guide who explained everything clearly and concisely.  Sixpacks of tea seem expensive at 2000 rupees but each pack of tea is 125g  for just under £1.50 so good value really for a class product.  Teaworkers were striking in Nuwara Eliya while we were there.  They want 1000 rupees a day instead of the current 850.  I so hope they get it as it is such a hard life.

We visited a number of tea factories and got tired of the hard sell. Pedro tea factory was different. It had a lovely feel. The lady who showed us around was really lovely. There tea is delicious and there was no hard sell at all. Highly recommend

It was a Sunday so the factory wasn’t working. We decided not to pay for a tour as we’d already seen one tea factory on a non-production day. They do let you wander the plantation which was nice, although there were no pickers working either. Free tea tasting - just one tea, and a very small shop. If you’re going, go on a production day.

Nearby the town and a great place to spend an hour or so during a rainy monsoon morning. Pleasant tea café and beautiful views; interesting to see how tea is processed (but be warned going upstairs is one of the hottest experiences ever -- the warm air from the drying process drifts upwards and literally a bit hard to breathe)!

If you're a tea drinker check this establishment out. The tour of the factory by an informative guide is well worth the time and the short trip out of town. The vistas are beautiful, however the shop only sells several packets of tea at a time, so if space in your luggage is limited you'll be disappointed.

Entrance costs 1,000 rupees per person, the tour is very short, about 15 minutes, and you can only see the machines themselves but you can't see the creature itself because it only happens at night. There's a feeling that the tour was done in an area only for tours and that they don't show the factory itself. The machines they look very dusty and outdated, really feel like a fake representative.
This tour gives a good insight to how tea is manufactured and is located in a very picturesque setting. The tour is not too long at 30 minutes and only costs R250 pp which we felt was reasonable.

After a wonderful train trip into the high country this tour did not in any way live up to our expectations. It was a rushed tour with the explanations of the workings of the plantations and the origins of Sri Lankan tea sadly lacking. We were taken around the facility but ended up with no further knowledge than we had arrived with. We were not shown any tea bushes or how they were picked. Sad to say the least as we had looked forward to this part of our journey. A video would have been altogether more enlightening .

Was heading for the Lover’s Leap, when I found this tea factory, and thought I’d buy some to bring back home. Tried to ask if it was organic, the women in the tea saloon didn’t understand, so after getting a hold on the manager, I sort of Got an answer: they are “sort of organic” he said - using some chemicals. They do seem to have great focus on social responsibility, like houses for all their workers, which is great. Their lightest tea was the best, in my opinion, but also the BOP.

We visited this factory on a Monday and there was no tea production happening so we were taken around the machinery which was not very interesting. Our tour guide spoke on auto pilot and was more interested in waving to her co-workers than in explaining anything to us. We were provided with a cup of tea afterwards but there was no explanation of what tea it was. At RP250 it is not expensive but it’s really not worth the time.

We were staying local to Pedro Tea Estate and visited one afternoon. Firstly we were offered free roaming of the tea plantation and walked down to near the lake, then had a complimentary tea & a tour. Hashini was very knowledgeable & explained the process very well. Photos were not allowed inside however the outside was very scenic. At the end, you could buy some of the tea made, which I assume is where revenue comes in. Overall I’d definitely recommend this experience!

We went for a tour to this factory. Our guide was a lady that spoke very unclear english. She guided us at a high speed through the production facility where nobody was working. Only during the night there is production. So after the tour we have seen all the machines but still do not know exactly how the production is being done. Afterwards you receive a cup of tea.
many varieties of tea and The tour was wonderful  The guide was explained everything nicely also price is cheap

Factory tour with the guide was very interesting and informative. They charge a  nominal fee of LKR250 for adults and my kids were allowed without a charge. They run the factory during the night shift only so couldn't see most machines working but despite that one would get a good sense of how tea is produced. We also walk down the tea bushes but didn't see any plucking activity in that part unfortunately. I would recommend this place to people who have not been to a tea factory before.

Our guide was friendly and the factory interesting. It did feel like we learnt the rudiments of the process and given we only had a limited time, this worked for us. If you want a more in depth bus-to-cup tour, you'll have to look elsewhere.

Went on tour of factory, could hardly understand the guide, nothing happening in the factory. Very little explanation of the picking process or tea varieties, offered a cup of tea at end of visit. I’m sure there are better places to visit.

The visit was hasty, the explanation in English difficult to understand from a rather rude companion. It is also the only tea factory and plantation where an entrance fee of 500 rupees is required. At the end you can make purchases in the shop. If you want to visit a plantation there are better solutions in the area, much larger and free.

The tour of the production facilities is 500 rupees each which I don't think is unreasonable. It was an informative session and there was no hard sell as mentioned in other reviews. In fact it was a bit of an effort to get a tasting and to buy. Views from the location are lovely and all in all well worth an hour or so.
very informative tour and a lovely setting well worth visiting and trying the teas - the tea is for sale also

We think it is just another Tea Factory. I too thought the same. I have being to many tea factories in my life. But the Pedro tea factory itself is different. The building structure is unique and as explained by my Friend Nadun Madushan, the Assistant Manager, it is built in the style of an Chocolate Factory. In order to maintain a high standard of quality, tea manufacturing is done only during the night when the weather is colder. Therefore, the action is very low during the day time. But don't be worried there are plenty of staff who are well trained to take you on a guided tour on how tea is manufactured. Due to security reasons the management doesn't allow anyone to take photographs inside the premises. Their tea boutique is also a very cozy place to visit and have a nice cup of tea and purchase whatever the flavor you wish to have. And over looking the tea boutique is the lovely scenery of the tea estate. Time spent here is very relaxing and memorable. This place is a must visit to anyone who visits the beautiful Nuwaraeliya.

We had a quick tour and explanation of how tea is made - it was fine but quick. I was most disappointed with the selection of gifts - I didn’t end up buying anything because the selection wasn’t great. The grounds were beautiful though.

As I am engaged in the tea sector ,I was much interested about this place but when I tasted the cup of tea I got much dissatisfied as they offered us a cup of tea made of Tea "DUST" thats one of the low cost tea which tastes awful and I totally disappointed with this experience. But I must say the view through the tea shop was quite nice  but i went there for tea so if you are looking for great cup of tea ..sorry ,thats would not be the place for such.

Great experience. 500LKR/pax for an interesting tour around the tea factory (photos prohibited) and a complimentary cup of tea. 1000LKR/pax to have a practical demo of tea picking, and 15/20 minutes to try it out yourself. 1100LKR/pax for tea tasting. Overall, a cheap and fun afternoon out!
Good tour around the factory and good to know the tea process... inside the factory is really dirty and tea spilled all over the place, my wife and kid found it difficult to walk...

All tea factories in Sri Lanka is same, we went to tea factory in Lipton seat, this one is also similar to that one, but the free tea they give after tour, is amazing ;) you have to pay 250 rupee per person...

One of our highlights to tea country was our trip to Pedro tea factory. The tour was amazing. The process was explained and we saw the machines and every step of tea production our guide was lovely and guided us with expertise and passion I was particularly impressed how they included a man on our tour who had an impairment. They were considerate of his needs and he wasn’t left out. Tea tasting st the end was great and we purchased tea to take home. Highly recommend if you love tea.

Non operational in the morning. Opening Hours: 8.30 AM Ticket: LKR 200/- with one cup of tea If you don't want to visit the factory, you can still visit the tea plantation without any charges. You can tip the workers in the plantation if you like. The hike in the fields in amazing.

We all had to have a picture of us in our green aprons you have to wear for the tour. The tour was nice - some very old equipment. Interesting how the different teas are made. Nice cup of tea on the deck overlooking a great view.

It's easy to join a group to take a tour of this factory. The tour runs really fast, and assumes you already know something about tea and how it is produced. After the tour is over they serve you a cup of tea produced in the area.
Chose the Pedro tea factory if you are wanting an authentic experience. Only 200 rupee per person for a guided tour with tea sample at the end.
They take you on a short tour of their tea factory and plantation. You have to pay a fee for the tour. You will to taste the tea grown there

This is where we purchase our tea from every time we visit Nuwara Eliya. We have visited Pedro tea factory over 5 times now. This was our 7 month old's first time though. The tea is superb and the view of the tea plantations from the viewing deck is a nice experience. We did experience the factory tour once which was very informative. Highly recommended for a nice experience if you enjoy Ceylon Tea.

Review Title: Not worth the time and money
Review Text: Dreadful tour. Charged 1k rupees to be show around the factory by someone that couldn’t be bothered. The staff were less than impressed that we had chosen their tour above all others. Don’t waste your time, here are many tours to go on and I wish we had picked a different one.

Comparatively a small factory built in 1885, yet an interesting tour. Located just 3.5 km from the Nuwaraeliya city center makes its one of the few factories closer to the town. As soon as you enter the premises , it’s start smelling tea. Tickets for the tour is available at the counter in  “Lover’s Leap” Ethical tea boutique. Boutique is located right opposite the car park down  towards the tea estate. Tickets comes with a free cup of tea which is free to enjoy before or after the tour. Boutique's clean and well maintained ambiance was so relaxing and offer a perfect view of the greeny tea estate. There was a fair collection of Ceylon tea to be purchased. However, lesser verities. Didn’t see a large collection of flavoured or infused teas. Reason may be this place only sells the pure tea straight from their factory without any infusions or additions. Only pure tea as it is. “Lover’s Leap”, the Boutique got this name in reference to a nearby waterfall with the same name. Supposedly the name was given after an ancient prince and his lover leapt into death from the particular waterfall. Tour was fairly short since the factory is small (just about 10-15 minutes). But worth the experience. What I loved most is purchasing different kinds of Ceylon tea. If your itinerary is too tight and does not permits much time to travel a factory too far from city or long tea tour, this is an ideal place.

It’s a pity that the group sizes are so big. We were shown around by a very sweet lady but unfortunately we couldn’t hear a word she said, due to the noise of the machinery. the gardens are pretty, and it was interesting to look around the factory but overall we felt that they should have more but small tour groups.

There are several competing tea factories that are vying to be the top tourist draw of tea country (massive hotels, all the trappings).  This one, while perfectly well set up for tourists, is clearly still mainly in the business of processing tea.  They have a nice reception area, and start you off with a cup of delicious local product.  Then they take you on a very informative tour, on which pictures are inexplicably forbidden (most of the machinery appears to date back to the early industrial revolution, I can't imagine a picture or two would disclose any top secrets but oh well). Guide books say nothing is going on because they do all their processing at night, but I actually saw this as an advantage:  no interference, we could walk around and not get in anyone's way.  Our guide was very knowledgeable.  Strongly recommended!!

Paid 250rupees for the tour.. it took about 20min all together.. the lady spoke very fast and rushed the whole process... She also asked whether she could give my change later however she didn't and I forgot about it so I don't know if she does that to everyone for side note to anyone reading this. We got some tea at the end and we didn't even know what kind of tea we we were drinking... The factory was cool inside and that's about it... I guess it's a must do for something to do in Nuwara Eliya. We took a stroll around the tea plantation which was nice and had some sick views of the dam and Mountains.

The walk through the tea factory followed by the cup of tea is a wonderful experience. The guides take you around the place which costs LKR 200 (only cash). Your tea comes with the mildest variant that they produce so it's something that you need to keep in mind
It's not a big thing, give yourself an hour or two max. But it's a lovely little trip very informative of tea production and cup of tea thrown into the mix for 200 rupees. So can't complain.

Visited the Tea factory couple of days back, it was a wonderful experience. The staff is very polite and knowledgeable. They speak  all three languages, property is in a beautiful location. it was indeed a very informative tour and the cup of tea at the end of the tour was a lovely touch.

This tea factory offers a tour of key production processes.  It is unfortunate that the factory is not actually operational during the daytime.  Explanations were clear and concise.  Refreshment is available and a small shop selling their products

Surrounded by beautiful tea plantations, the Pedro Tea Factory was a great place to visit. We had a lovely friendly tour guide who took us round the factory, although by the time we got there, it wasn't actually in use. Our guide was knowledgeable and explained everything really well, and the tea at the end was a lovely treat!

We enjoy drinking tea and had never experienced what goes into growing and processing tea until we visited the Pedro Estate Nuwaraeliya tea factory. Enjoyable day out in very scenic part of Sri Lanka. Very clean and tidy facilities and great cup of tea. About 20 minute drive from city centre. Great drive. Our tour guide Sivakavj at the Banquet Boutique was the perfect guide with excellent knowledge and very friendly customer support. Ask for her personally and you will not be disappointed.

The young lady guide was pleasant but the factory tour showed how many manual processes are yet to be automated. The newest machines seemed to be from 1986. As the factory operates between midnight and 0600 hours when the area is at its coolest, all we could watch was a couple of workers separating picked tea leaves as well as others carrying heavy bundles between sites. Some visitors went down a hill to see how an employee picks the leaves.  It needs skill, and constant avoidance of thorns.  Not a job I'd have ever enjoyed, especially given the midday heat. The gift shop was the focus of the estate.  Along with a cup of tea it concluded the experience.

We simply turned up and tours were running pretty much all the time (every 15 minutes roughly, each time enough people we waiting for them to run one), it was 200 LKR each (we visited on 16-02-2017) and the tour rook about 20 minutes. After the tour they gave us free tea to try and we went for a walk around the tea gardens. You can buy all the tea they grow there. The tour was in English.
Really interesting and informative tour is very workwhile. Explains a lot about the industry how tea is made and the history

On arriving we were given a cup of the plantation tea, which was delicious, and we were able to sit out on the balcony overlooking the plantation and enjoy the morning sunshine and lovely views. The tire was interesting although quite short, I would have liked to also have a chance to learn about how they pick the tea and look after the plants (it focuses on the processing of the tea after it is picked). Still very interesting however. It can be hard to hear the guide on the factory of you have a large group. The factory promotes worker welfare and ethical tea practices, there are interesting signboards in the visitor centre about the factory's history and engagement in UN programmes.

We had a tour of this tea factopry during our 6 day tour of Sri Lanka. The two, of us were taken round by a very knowledgeable young lady who was able to answer all of our questions. Unfortunately photography isn't allowed inside the factory but I did manage to get one picture which gives you an idea of what it's like

I wasn’t really into this, but my lady was and the tuk tuk driver recommended it... you’ll take a 15 minute walk through the factory and see how tea is made... they let you have a tasting and hope you’ll buy something.

We were supposed to go to Damro but went here instead as land slides had blocked the road. A very average factory tour: the attendant walked us through the entire tea-manufacturing process in their factory. Nothing spectacular, just an average tour. They didn't have a lot of varieties of tea for sale either.

The friendly guides at the tea factory give you a reasonably comprehensive tour of the tea drying and preparation process. You end up with, what else, a nice cup of tea and it was actually one of the nicest cups of tea I've ever had. A good learning experience.
Lovely old tea factory in the hills.  we were given a tour of the factory and shown  how the leaves are processed. At the end we got to taste 2 kinds of tea. The tea is brewed for exactly 5 minutes.

The tea factory is among a huge tea plantation. They take you on the tour in groups, while waiting for your turn or after the tour you can relish their complimentary tea drink. There is an fee of 200lkr that is charged, so in case you plan on visiting other places in Nuwara Eliya then one of the bigger tea plantations would be a better option since the tours here dont have charges.

We were not so impressed with the tour at this factory. First of all the factory was not in action. I guess because it was a Sunday. So you look at a bunch of machines and try to figure out how it works. The tour leader was very hard to hear because of the noise of cleaning the machines. The good thing is that Pedro works in a very friendly way for the environment, fair trade and so on. The tour itself was however not so great.

It starts off at about 8.15am, and involves a guided tour of the tea factory itself. This is not a massive tour group; each visiting group is taken on their own tour by a guide, even if the group consists of just 2 people! Literally no waiting time. The tour itself is very interesting, & he guide is knowledgeable and entertains questions asked by guests. After the tour, guests are allowed to roam the tea plantation by themselves! No one breathing down your back or watching your every move... Haha! Total freedom in a lovely tea estate.... finally, the tour ends with a warm cup of Sri Lankan tea. I thoroughly enjoyed this tour...!

Not being much of a tea drinker, I found the factory tour interesting and informative.  But what fascinated me more were the tea pickers who worked 8 hours a day with a daily goal of picking 18 kilograms a day, all for less than $5 USD.

We went to this on our way to Heritance Tea Factory. Unfortunately it was a Sunday so the factory wasn’t working but we saw a tea factory and got a good explanation of its working. Worth the hour stop. They don’t allow photos. No idea why not.

Pedro tea factory is near Nwara Eliya and not too far from Heritance Tea Factory. The guide spoke perfect English and the tour of the working factory very interesting. You can see all phases of tea production. There is a small shop where you can buy their local tea and you can taste it.
Nice to see how they made tea, tour is not long but interesting, you can not take pictures inside the building. You can buy tea at the factory
Good tour and an interesting insight into how tea is picked and prepared for packaging. Also has great views of the tea estate and a nice place to relax and drink tea (what else)

Potential not exploded. Could be amazing, stays on average. Good tea and views at the end. Nothing special. What a pity. The explanation is made while they dont have much going on. Hard to see it in action. Mainly cos they work at night. Hope to come back in the future and see it shining.

Pedro Tea Factory is not quite as fancy as others in the area but definitely worth a visit. The staff was friendly and helpful. There is a outside area where you can have a cup of tea and enjoy the beautiful view.

During our sri lanka trip we also wanted to visit a tea factory and since our accomodation in nuwara eliya was close to the san pedro facility we went there for a tour around noon. The entrance fee has meanwhile increased to 250 rupees which is still not very high, but the whole tour took also only around 20 minutes and was not very informative. At noon there was no production in the factory that day, however with production in the background we would have probably not understood our tour guide. We got a cup of tea afterwards but also without any further comments or explanation. Seems the quality of the tours in this factory has quite a wide variation.

Visited early in the morning as an alternative activity to our trip to Horton Plains being cancelled. They were extremely helpful, despite the electricity being off, they managed to make us a hot and welcome cup of tea and a tour of the factory. The tour is free and there is a small shop to purchase the estate Tea from. It is useful to offer the factory guide a small tip of 100/200 rupees. The factory is full of the most original machinery much of which is still in operation today, so if you are a lover of this sort of thing, you would definitely enjoy a visit. I was surprised at how quickly tea leaves are turned into tea, within 24 hours and that the aluminium lined bags they pack the tea into at the end of the process can keep the tea for upto 2 years. The estate announces that it is an ethical company with some opportunity for the workers to be involved and would appear to offer more medical care and education than some others do. I wasn't sure about this place as there were some remarks about the speed of the tour and the guides accent, but we did not feel rushed at all and the guide was clear, helpful and very friendly.

i've visited them today and was a great learning experience actually! my guide was a young Sri Lankan lady that had a great knowledge of tea and what goes into prepering a perfect cup. at the end of tje tpur they offer you one of the best orange pekoe i've tasted....

This tour is quite dull. It only took about 10 minutes, and no photos are allowed. If it was a free tour, it would be fine, but I'm not sure it's worth paying for. We saw the tea factory at the Heritance Tea Factory hotel- it was free, and much better.

I only ever leave reviews when things are really good, or very bad and this was very VERY BAD. We had wanted to do the factory tour and were told on our arrival that we weren’t able to because the factory wasn’t open for visitors that day (oddly). We were told that the only two activities we could do where the two (more expensive at 1100 Rs pp) “experiences” of Tea tasting or Tea picking; we opted for the tea tasting. We said we understood that the factory was closed for tours but asked if it would be possible to pop our heads round to see the inside of the factory? The woman said yes. So we sat down for our tea tasting, and after 10 minutes a tray of tea was plonked in front of us, a different woman pointed and said some teas were strong and others weren’t, and then departed(!) There was no explanation about the variations of tea on the tray, how they are grown, or what they were even! Nothing. Nada. We were just left to our tray of random teas. It was an absolute joke. We tried to find someone to ask questions but got minimal information and no actual explanation on the process. We then said asked if we could have a quick look round the door at the factory, and the woman in charge said “yes that’s fine, that’ll be Rs.350 each” i.e. the cost of the tour which we had initially asked for and were told that we couldn’t do!! I queried why we were told merely 15 minutes earlier that we couldn’t do the tour of the tea factory, at which point the woman basically lied to us and claimed she had included it as an option!! She was basically scoffing at us as she spoke implying that all 3 of us had misunderstood. The Sri Lankan driver who had driven us there and was waiting and had heard the whole thing was as shocked as we were at the audacity of this woman. (And won’t be recommending anyone go there again). This is an absolute waste of time please avoid and don’t make the same mistake we did by going to this shambles of a factory.

An interesting guided tour of the factory followed by a cup of their tea.  Only one of their products was available to sample as part of the price.  It would have been good to sample other blends as we had done at other tea fctories.  Price was 200 Rupees, which was reasonable

-We went as a couple -A free tea at arrival was very nice and is for sale -the factory tour was very cheap and it lasted about 30mins. The lady doing the tour was very nice and the tour was informative -we had a short walk around the tea fields and its beautiful -i would recommend visiting this tea factory Thanks Sam

For us, however, it was a beautiful experience: the plantation tries to respect ethics and sustainability criteria and for this reason it differs from the others. We visited the factory with the original 19th century machinery still working and the explanation was concise but exhaustive. At the end they offered us an excellent cup of tea, accompanied by a freshly fried spicy 'rollo': delicious.
We had a very short, but still interesting tour in the fabric with the basic information about the producing of tee. Afterwards you get a couple of tee (no need to pay extra).

Quick run through the production plant followed by two samples of tea to taste. Then you must buy. I was hoping to visit the tea plantation, but that was not part of the tour -perhaps due to the inclement weather. Not bad, fairly educational, wouldn't have felt too bad about missing this one.
Interesting tour which shows you from start to finish how tea is produced. The machinery wasn’t working the day we went but the tea tour was still worth it. Free cuppa at the end.

We visit Pedro tea factory in August 2018. It is only 10 minutes to Nuwara Eliya the factory is working only nights. They made a quick tea factory tour and served a cup of tea at the end of the tour. They are selling also their own tea. You are paying 250 rupies ( less than 2usd)  for person. You may find another place which is free on the way from Kandy to Nuwara Eliya.
The visit at Pedro Estate was so nice. We could take a walk through the beautiful garden, taste delicious black tea and got a very interesting tour through the factory.
Guide was very knowledgeable and was focused on explaining the tea making process rather than selling tea!
The visit was nice but a little bit short. We had a “free” tea cup at the end of the visit. The views are beautiful from the factory.

On arrival we were given the option of tea factory tour for Rs 250 or tea picking for Rs1000. We went for the latter which turned out to be a huge mistake. We were shown how to pick one tea leaf then left to our own divides for 20 minutes, whilst the guide was preoccupied with her phone. We were not told anything about the tea plantation or the tea picking process. After this we were taken on a tour of the factory, but all the machinery was off as they only use the factory at night. During the tour the guide was more interested with her friends, giggling and waving at them, than giving us any real information about the factory. She also spoke in autopilot and was inspiring. Overall a very disappointing visit and not worth the money. This trip was unforgettable for all the wrong reasons.
Very disappointing visit lasting 10 minutes for a cost of 500 rupees. We visited with a couple who had been to other much nicer free tea factories. Incomplete visit

Don’t go on Saturday. There’s nobody working. The tour is done in 10 minutes (does not include the fields, just the factory) and the price is not worthy (at least at the weekend). I have visited other tea factories for free and you just pay for what you buy. Here we were charged 500LKR per person for practically nothing. A waste of money and time during the weekend.

This is a very historical site in the tea industry. Pedro owns Lovers Leap. Unfortunately the lunch bell rang at 1pm and all the pickers in the plantation and people in the factory disappeared for 1 hour. There was no activity in the factory and the tour guide said they make the tea at night. She struggled to answer my questions and couldn’t say the difference between black tea and green tea. It would have been helpful to have an information sheet in English. There was no tea tasting either. Good view of the plantation though. Pickers willing to have photo taken if money given. I didn’t realise til after the visit about the historical importance of Pedro, that wasn’t mentioned either. They are marketing themselves as an eco centre also, but again not sure why? There is a huge woodshed out the back that seems to run the original equipment from the 1890’s.
For 100rp you get a 20min tour of the production process from them delivering the tea from the field to the packaging.  Was interesting.

We were really disappointed with our visit to Pedro Tea Factory. Firstly when we arrived noone greeted us, the staff all ignored us and it was really unclear where we were supposed to go. We figured out we had to buy tickets and were then told to wait 10 minutes until the tour started. We waited 30 minutes without any further communication about the tour. Another staff member did give us a cup of tea but with no explanation, we weren't really sure if it was actually supposed to be for us. We chose a table to sit at, but they were all very dirty with bits of food and flies and dishes unclear from previous guests. Finally our tour guide came to get us for our tour, she was very unenthusiastic and came across as in a hurry and disinterested. During the tour, our guide was very rude to other guests in our group. The guide's accent was a bit hard to understand at the best of times (not her fault as English is her second language), but she told two members of our tour group (who English was also not their first language for) that taking photos was not allowed. They clearly did not hear her/understand what was being said, and instead of gently making sure they understood, she yelled at them "do you even speak English?!". After the tour was finished she just walked off without saying goodbye or thanks or anything. Such a bad experience from start to finish! The previous day we did a tour at Damro and it was amazing! I'd definitely recommend avoiding Pedro and going to Damro instead.
probably best to see during the wek we went on a saturday and nothing working guide was pleasant and tea afterwards refreshing no hard sell which was nice as well
Generally good Tea Factory and Explain also good. Helpful staff and they served a Good Tea as well. Tea Field is good and well maintained.
Visited here on our mini tour of Sri Lanka, excellent visit with really good guide. You would never understand how much time and effort goes into a cup of tea when drinking it back home

To be fair, it was interesting and was set in stunning Countryside. We learned about the tea making process and that was an enjoyable experience - but because they make ‘light’ tea most of the really interesting work and processing is done overnight, meaning the tour was primarily around an empty and quiet factory - more like a museum tour, which is not what it was billed as. Worth it ifyou have time to kill and are in the area, but would not go out of your way. Plus, as always, the shop is very overpriced.
They took us Factory Tour and explain Tea producing procedure A - Z.  Offered nice cup of Tea.   You can buy fresh Tea as well.

If you are a Tea drinker, this is a must place to visit. The factory visit gives you a glimpse of how your favourite tea is made and tasting it. They offer some of their teas for free to try them but others are just for buying.
The place is a working tea  factory. They make a real effort to be both welcoming and informative. You get a well explained tour of the whole factory and emerge with a better understanding about tea.

We were taken to this plantation and factory by our driver as part of a planned itinery. The tour of the plant was very informative and the guide spoke extremely well. We left very informed, just unfortunate that we didnt see the factory in action (works at night), and couldnt take photos in the factory.  Got to taste some tea (without milk as its not the done way), and walk amongst the plantation. We left satisfied that we had been to what we wanted to see and hear, but feel there could have been more. Sadly didnt see anyone picking leaves, but that was just where we were at the time. All family happy.

Average place to see tea garden, little bit of history of tea industry in Sri Lankan hill country. You could walk down the tea bushes. You can buy tea and refresh yourself with a nice and warm cup of tea.

Even though the factory was not working (tea production occurs at night here) the guided tour was very informative.  The tea rooms are quite nice and offer great views out over a picturesque section of the plantation.  The cup of tea was lovely also!

Unfortunately the size of the tour group (about 20) was too large for the factory tour guide to manage However, the tour was still interesting in terms of the process of making tea from growing to packaging for the market Tea can be purchased at very reasonable prices.

Short (15 min) visit to the factory for 200 LKR per person with a free cup of tea afterwards on a terrace with beautiful view. Our guide looked little bit annoyed. Not allowed to take pictures inside. It is easily reachable by public bus from the city centre (around 25 LKR per person, 15min). You can also take a walk from here to the Lover's Leap watterfall.

Visited Pedro having been left wanting on a trip to Stone Gate the previous day. Pedro is actually based on the plantation and you can see the tea plants and pickers in action. Good tour and explanation, but machines aren’t working as the quality of tea they produce is made at night (when cooler to slow down the the fermentation process) and I guess it would be dangerous anyway to walk around a factory in production anyway. Nice cup of tea afterwards, and a very soft sell in the shop, with really good prices. Afterwards had a wander through the tea plants and then walked up to Lovers Leap. Well worth a visit.

The price of the tour is not much, but the commentary was pretty uninspiring. The only two sections of the factory working at the time was the sorting of the finished tea into its various grades from the top grade orange pekoe to the tea dust.  We did see the first process but I didn't hear the name where the leaves are initially dumped in big bays to be dried with wood fire heat to remove enough moisture from the leaves to make them rubbery and then allow the rolling process. But there was no machine on to show the rolling, the fermentation, or the cutting etc. After seeing the sorting, we saw the packaged product ready for auction, then  it was back to the shop for a cup of their tea but no explanation of what we were drinking etc. So a pretty short and basic tour of the factory with a commentary that hard to hear at the best of times, but was inaudible when the sorting machine was on. We didn't see any tea pickers.  I think by the afternoon they were all clocking off. The tea fields were nice to look at.  The tea in the cafe was nice.
Visit this place for a nice cup of tea and to buy tea leaves. Also they do factory tours where the kids can learn the routine and tasks of a tea factory.

I've visited many tea plantations in India and Sri Lanka. The tour here was very good and everything well explained. The guide didn't take us into the plantations or explain about Silver tips, white and green tea. Also, the tea offered after the tour is nice but the Damro tea factory is much better for a relaxing tea (free) and cake (paid) overlooking the plantations. Blue Field is also good to visit.

Nice little tour that explains all about tea production, you get to see all the equipment and a guide with a decent cuppa afterwards. Very relaxed and interesting insights into employment practice from the various worker notices on the walls. We combined with a walk up to Lovers Leap waterfall about 40 minutes round trip through the tea plantations Smiles all round, we took the  bus back to NE, no bother Admission 500 LKR well worth it.

A three wheeler from Nuwara Eliya centre to the Pedro costs 350-400 rupees. The estate is in a picturesque setting and the tour is very reasonably priced at 250 rupees per person. Pedro cares about its staff and the environment - both important factors when considering which plantation to visit. The workers were off and the cleaners were in when we went round, that was fine as they warned us. The best part was talking to the tea pluckers at the end. And the cup of orange pekoe!

I visit with my guest to buy tea. Then i wait 1/2 hour for factory visit so return from factory wait 1/2 hour again for tea taste. Very bad restaurant area toilet smel always. After buy tea wait 1/2 hour paid bill one lady is working issuing factory entrace ticket explain tea cash collect. I dont know why managemet sleep like this i m giving instruction all visitors dont go for time weast.

Everything about the visit was bad. Not sure if we got a particularly unmotivated guide, but she just repeated what she memorized and explained what each machine does. We asked several follow up questions, but her answer was not insightful. Also, we all get free tea but honestly the tea tasted worst than the cheapest tea I drink back home. They provide third grade tea. After drinking that tea, I definitely didn’t want to buy any tea from the factory. Lastly, now the tour fee is 250 lak. Overall, it was a waste of time. I could google and drink better tea at home.
Their prime intention is to make you purchase their products. the climate is very soothing. can visit.

Unlike the Damro plantation you have to pay for a factory tour - which wasn’t actually productive at the time of our visit ,  just running the sizing side of the process.  We waited an age in the foyer for any instructions on where and when the tour would start. The lady who finally showed up led us off in too large a group size - such that only those directly next to her could hear her.

Beautiful experience of watching ladies picking tea leaves (very friendly to chat to) walking through fields and understanding the tea process. After the tour a complimentary cup of tea was provided. Very enjoyable tour. Advice to come there before 4pm if you want to see the machines still working.
Nice tea shop. Offers guided tours in the tea factory. At the end of the tour you are served a cup of tea in the café with a nice view. You can take walk in the hills.
It was a Sunday they were washing down the machinery and finishing production, fascinating. Like stepping back in time.

Situated proudly as the tea factory at the highest elevation within Sri Lanka the factory produces some of the best tea in the world. A tour can be organised on arrival to see the process. A tea shop also allows you to taste and buy some tea.

Stunning nature surrounds this old tea factory, which is still in full activity. The tours around the factory gives you a good insight in the process of tea making, and makes you humble to every glass of tea you drink thereafter. Also, seeing the hard work of the tea picking ladies, makes you wonder why the tea are not more expensive, and you really wish someone would increase their income a bit. If you take a picture with them, be wise enough to give them a few hundred rupees - they will appreciate the added income

Went round as a small group, unfortunately due to the rain the factory wasn't operating so we couldn't see it in action. However it was good to see and learn about the process & machinery, the guide though wasn't able to tell us anything about the history and was unable to answer a lot of questions.

We did a short tour here. I enjoyed seeing the old factory and old machines that are all still in use. You can see some old photos as well  of important people who have visited over the years. A good explanation of how tea is made. A nice cuppa at the end as well.

The factory tour itself cost 500LKR and for that you get to walk around the factory and see all the different machines and different stages of the tea making process. Our tour Gide spoke very good English and took the time to answer questions.  The tour maybe lasted around 20-30mins.  You can then sit in the cafe and taste one of the teas for free. There is also a gift shop.  The views are really nice.

I’ve been to several tea factories in Sri Lanka and Pedro is nice as you get to see a working factory. Sadly on the day we went it was not operating due to a public holiday but nevertheless you get to see inside it and you can tell that it’s not just a display factory like many others I’ve been to. The tour was only 200rps and included a cup of tea at the end (which wasn’t great). I wouldn’t buy tea here but if you’re into your tea and want to see a functioning factory it’s worth a visit.

Make sure before you pay for the tour that you check that it actually is a production day. We payed only to find it was not even in operation that day. It was informative even though it wasn't running.

We went here for the tour and tea picking experience. Tour was very informative but you weren’t allowed to take photos. I was impressed some of the machines were installed in 1950s- built to last in those days! Tea from here is wholesale sold on to big companies who blend it to their own specifications. There were 65kg bags in the packing area! At the end you get a cup of tea to try. Being a photographer I really wanted to get some photos of the tea pickers but it seemed they weren’t working the Monday we went. We managed to see some further out of town so got some pictures then. Worth a visit!

I had already visited two tea factories so i did not bother taking the tour, but i rested in the cafe where i watched a documentary about Pedro Tea Estate and then enjoyed a free cup of tea. However there were quite a few people taking the tour and they seemed satisfied. I hiked here after passing by Lover'sLeap waterfall, but the last kilometer is along a busy road which was not too enjoyable.

Wonderful visit set in a wonderful area. Staff friendly and a great tour around the working tea production. Tastings offered of various teas and the opportunity to purchase. Really enjoyed the tour and very well explained how teas are dried and prepared. Highly recommended and thank you for allowing the public to visit.

Pedro tea factory offers its visitors an interesting guided tour of the factory, giving valuable insight to all aspects of tea such as, steps of processing, types of tea, how it is being marketed etc. This factory belongs to a well established tea plantation group that supplies teas to many well known brands in the country, such as Dilmah. Guides speak good English and are professional and friendly. The tour takes only about 30 minutes. One must purchase an entry ticket which costs around Rs.250/= per person. *** Make sure to be there by 8.00 am in order to see the factory in full operation as they start their processing work very early in the morning. If you happen to go later in the day, you can still get a tour of the factory but you will not get to see as much, since the work is mostly done by mid morning and the workers get on with cleaning the machinery. Nevertheless, it would still be educational and worthwhile. At the end of your tour, you get to enjoy a complimentary cup of freshly brewed tea while enjoying the view of their beautifully maintained tea gardens. They also sell some fine teas, if you wish to purchase any. These teas are of very good quality, you'll not regret buying some.

This was one of the main reasons for our trip to Sri Lanka and this was such a disappointment. The tour when it got underway was taken by a lady guide who seemed so un-interested in her job and the customers were an inconvenience. It was so rushed and a large group whereby it was difficult to hear what was being said. This lady did not appear to want to be there and her body language exuded this. It was so rushed. Very very disappointing, don't waste your money, a small as the fee is, or more importantly your time you will be under whelmed
It is worth taking the time to do the tour: very informative and interesting! It only takes 30 minutes, and then you can their Tea.

The factory tour was very quick and it was difficult to hear what the guide was saying. Explanations (what we heard) were exceptionally brief and we were not allowed to really look at the process or take photographs.

I have visited the Pedro factory twice now, once with my partner and a second time with my Mum. It is very reasonably priced at just 200rs for a 20-30 minute guided tour and cup of tea. Our guide Kalaivane was superb! Friendly, informative and the daughter of a tea picker so able to gave a very personal and honest account of the tea industry. An enlightening experience I would definitely recommend!

We intended to go on a factory tour, but they told us the factory wasn’t running at the moment. We decided to do a tea tasting instead. 6 cups of tea were put in front of us without any explanation.. I then asked someone for an explanation, she just told me which cup was which tea, no further explanation.

We came here in the afternoon of our day trip to Nuwara Eliya after riding the scenic train. Blue Lanka, our tour agency, recommended it so we thought we would give it a try. The factory is wonderful and the guide of the factory spoke great english. It was great to see the tea making in progress and smell the tea in its rawest form. Then, there was the tea tasting. The first couple teas come free while the others cost money to taste. All the teas are great and they bring out an additional rare (we don't know if it actually was) tea for us to try. This tea was 150 USD per kilo....the tea plantation was wide, beautiful and spacious. The tea ladies always beckon you over for photos (and tips). Overall, a wonderful tea plantation and I would recommend coming here.

Went to this factory to see the tea process.  As others have said, nothing working on the day.  We got a guide who was very quietly spoken and difficult to hear.  She told me off for having my camera open and when I asked her a question she told me to ask one of the tourists and flounced off in a huff, bringing our tour to an end.  Nice location but staffer was rude.  She was the only rude Sri Lankan we came across in our 1 month holiday, so it really left an impression (not a good one).
We had a nice tour and learned a lot about tea. Try to visit on Tuesday through Friday. On Monday there is not tea to process since they don't pick on Sunday- something we learned to our chagrin.

This wasn't a planned visit...on our way back from Lover's Leap our tuk driver suggested a visit to take part in their factory tour.... even though we've done this a couple of times before we thought why not and proceeded.... And it turned out be the best tea factory tour we've had so far! It was a precise and concise tour of 20 mts where they take you through each division of the factory while explaining the tea making process from end to end. And it was also the most informative of all the tea factory tours we've had so far. The lady who did the tour did an excellent job. She was very knowledgeable and answered many questions. We went there around 10.30 am and immediately joined a tour that was just about to start. After the tour you get a nice cup of tea. (I think there are tours every half an hour.) If you arrive while a tour is ongoing they will serve you tea first which you can enjoy in their tea lounge while enjoying the lovely view. We paid LKR 500 each and I think it was the same for locals and foreigners. No photos or videos are allowed inside the factory. [If I am nitpicking, the aprons they provide visitors to wear during the tour can do with a makeover.] We Also learnt that the name of the Estate is pronounced as "Peedro" (not "Pedro")  same as how the British colonists called "Piduruthalaga" the highest mountained "Mount Pedro", pronounced as "Mount Peedro". The factory is quite close to Nuwara Eliya town. Road conditions are good. It's on the side of the Udupussellawa road and there is ample parking inside the property. They also have a collection of single estate tea for sale. If you are interested in touring a tea factory and learning about the tea making process I would highly recommend this tour.

Given the importance of tea to Sri Lanka it seemed odd not to try and learn a little about the history of the industry, the people who work in it and the journey it makes from the beautifully cultivated hillsides to our daily brew. This tour, which took around 2 hours touches on most of the those topics. Having been warmly received in a very modern facility, we were each given a gown to wear and ushered off in a small group tour of the facility. This starts with learning about the picking process and the pickers, moves to the drying and a discussion about what makes each type or grade of tea, to the rolling, sorting and packing. Our tour guide was a 4 th generation lady who was excellent and handled even the toughest question with an interesting answer. We liked her a lot as it was obvious what she was doing mattered to her. With the tour over you get to enjoy a nice cuppa. If you are in the area you really should do one of these tours and this one is pretty decent.

We took this tour and another on the same day, this tour was educational and we learnt a lot about the tea making process which is good however there was no option to walk around the plantation after the tour, it seemed as though it was more effort and nobody came to show us the gift shop either which was strange. The tour cost 250LKR pp. It was a rather hurried trip and we only stayed for around 30 mins from arrival time to leaving. Other plantations offer a more relaxed welcome.

Spent an hour being shown around the factory having the process explained to us. This was followed by a taste of their tea in a very pleasant café. Tea was so good I ordered some when I got home. Good way to spend some time.

Did both factory and picking tour (1000 rp each). Factory not working Sunday and no pickers because of wind, however an excellent tour ... very good English. Tea tasting was a single cup, but very nice. Picking was fun and got some good photos. Very close to Nuwara Eliya and lovers leap waterfall
Did the detailed survey of tea factory . where we wereexplained of how the different kinds of tea powders are made

We paid £26.71 per person for 6 people for a private tour.  The tour company didn't realise it was a public holiday and so there were no pickers on site and the factory wasn't working.  There were people on site who greeted us and actually did give us a tour but, not realising we had pre-booked the visit, they said it would cost us SLR200 each - i.e. approximately £1!  So - in essence, we paid £25 for a very expensive taxi ride from our hotel to the tea plantation approximately 3 km away!  You can turn up at the Pedro Tea Plantation at any time and be given a tour for SLR 200 and the price of a Tuk Tuk from town.  Having said that, the tour was very interesting.

Nice tea estate and one of the oldest. Tour of the factory is not free. There are other 2 tea factories in Nuwara Eliya , which I believe are better in terms of service. Staff seemed to be least interested in selling the products, which is unusual for Sri Lanka.
Had a great experience . Wonderful day and great fun. A wide variety of items. Good explanation of all the different types of items

We learnt more from our guide before we got to this place. It was interesting but missing parts of information regarding the growing of tea. It would have been more interesting if the factory was actually working the afternoon we visited. We were told they only function at night due to the correct temperature for processing tea.

The guide tried her best, but she is average and her explanations were very general and not insightful. The factory is in operation only at night hence the instruction given to us on the process was  more or less in theory. The factory has a good view but still not worth the price you pay and the time spent.

We were greeted with a hot cup of team (no milk or cookies) but it was refreshing. It requires a small fee to enter inside the factory. Unfortunately we visited it on Sunday so we could not see if live but we still received a guided tour of the factory inside and how tea is made .

Tea factory with factory tour and shop plus nice views. We had a brief group tour which cost 250LKR each for approx 30min tour. The tour guide was arguing with workers for a long period of time and I got the sense we were not welcome to watch the workers load up tea. That said we had a rudimentary tour of the factory and I left with more knowledge about tea than I came with. At the end we all had a complimentary cup of tea which was very nice and were encouraged to buy some tea at the shop. I think the tea here is better than other places but a bit disappointed by the tour.

One can learn all about tea making in this beautiful tea factory. A guided tour takes you around the tea factory and the guide explains to the group all about the process involved from the time the tea leave is plucked to the entire process of drying and the end product which we drink!
Lovely, quaint, old tea factory. Tour was very informative and views were fantastic. Tea quite expensive.
The tour was short and underwhelming. I came out with as little knowledge as I went in.  Far nicer is the Hertance tea hotel.
The factory tour is extremely well presented and any questions from the visitors were well dealt with.  Not to be missed if one has the opportunity to go
The tour was excellent throughly explained how the tea was made from start to finish. Would recommend

We went into the visit without expecting much; there were mixed reviews so we just hoped it would either be good or funny if it was a total failure. After paying for our tour (250LKR per person) we had to wait for a guide to arrive, although this only took a few minutes. After the guide arrived we went into the factory. It was pretty... empty. It also seemed like the woman who gave us the tour was sick and tired of her job because she zoomed through the factory like a Formula 1 car with rockets strapped on the back. I also think it will be pretty hard for most non-native English speakers to understand what the guide is saying. The whole tour wasn't very convincing, nothing was working and there wasn't much of an impression to be gained from the tour. Moreover, the tour seemed kind of fake, after we noticed the "bags with tea" in the storage room had a text on them saying they were from March 2018. TL;DR - It was a short but decently fun tour, just don't go in with too many expectations because you will most likely be disappointed.

Review Title: Ok if you never visited a tea factory but staff would have finished work so machineries will be silent and place empty .
Review Text: Having visited a working factory previously , I was disappointed to pay 1000 Rupees each person to wait for a group to form then start the visit. No photos allowed inside the factory.The girl gave good explanation but at times it was difficult to hear what she said. Only the fanning was working when the tea leaves separated debris thus dusts on the floor and staff cleaning machines. Only worth buying Pedro tea as nowhere else sells it ! 95 % for export and only 5 % probably in the shop . It’s the tea brits drink under different names!

We had a fascinating guided tour of the factory and learned all about the tea picking, withering and packing process. We then had a cup of tea and wandered through the plantation itself. Highly recommended.

While the guide was fine, it wasn't a very rounded tour. They should start with showing tea plucking, through the factory with showcasing the old wood burners and letting people see the different grades. It should end with a tea tasting where ppl can try to taste the differences. Great location and definitely worth taking the walk to the waterfall as well. The guides (I overheard a few while we were there) should try to introduce themselves and give a little personal story of their relationship to the estate. I would assume our guide was the daughter of a estate worker who has learned english and is now guiding groups which is nice to see.

It wasn't a production day, no ladies in the plantation picking pekoe leafs, only a open day to have a stroll trough the plantation slopes, but this was beautiful. The shop was open for tea tasting and a lot of different types of Ceylon Black Tea for sale :)  (it was february)

We had an excellent walk up to this place from our hotel at the quiet end of the lake. It's a peaceful walk (more interesting than tuktuk) We didn't do the tea factory tour but enjoyed a free cuppa overlooking the beautiful tea gardens and bought tea that was surprisingly well priced compared to the previous tea factory we visited. We then took a gorgeous walk up to lovers leap waterfall. Highly recommended. NB get the bus back into town from here,it's cheap as chips and do walk up to the waterfall the views are stunning

Really enjoyed the short visit here. The tour guide was really good, knew her stuff and very friendly to chat to. Visited on Christmas Day when the processing wasn’t happening so can’t comment on what it would be like on a working day.
We bought almost all the tea from the shop and it’s really tasted! the explanation of how they make the tea is really curious

Went here to have a look at the lounge .. it’s beautiful surrounded and overlooking the tea estate !! A cup of tea here just to sit and watch the view is great .. went venturing out in the tea estate itself plucking tea leaves !! The tea cake wasn’t the most delicious ones I’ve had but it was okie !!

They first take you on a tour around the place showing you how tea leaves are taken through various processes and result in the final product-tea powder.After that they give you a hot cup of tea which is very soothing and refreshing.They also sell tea packets freshly prepared in the factory at a nominal price.Overall a good way to spend  1 hr!!!

The people try to force you to do the tour. The place is small and not as beautiful as other tea locations such as Talawakelle Tea Estate and Edinburgh Tea Estate. I would personally avoid and go to the above.

Nice setting especially combined with a walk to Lover’s Leap Waterfall Factory tour is 250rp - we went on a Sunday and not much was happening so better to try another day.  It was nice walking around the tea plantation.  Staff were friendly and the cup of tea great.

Visited with my dad, and we had a lovely walk down to the tea plantains were we could see the ladies busy at work. They were doing guided tours of the factory for a small price but as the machines were not working we did not join in. We did sit in the cafe and enjoy a lovely cup of tea. Found the service to be a little slow- but pleasant all the same.

Good tour with a guide explaining the processes. Interesting to see how old the machinery was and still working. Strangely no photography allowed. Nice views outside of the reception area but not impressed with shop.
20 mins away from Nuwara Eliya city center,we bought tea leaves,I think tea leaves are in good quality,don't know excellent,price is too reasonable,anyhow we  enjoyed lot,

Pedro tea factory is situated closer to Nuwaraeliya city limits. You can take a tuk-tuk from the town or bus which travels on udupussellawa road. You'll get a brief while moving on a factory visit about the tea making process where you can clarify yourself and finally you can enjoy a hot cup of Ceylon tea as well. :)

One of the good factory visits and tea plantations. Reach there early before 9 AM to see the tea processing in action. Its ok to also go there later during the day, the tour person will walk you around the factory. Its a good educational tour for the kids.
A nice tea factory where they make primarily black tea. Staff is nice which takes you through the factory and explain the process.

Nice tea factory to visit. Thought I preferred the Ceylon Tea Museum near Kandy. But if you are in Nuwara Eliya and you didn't already visited something like that, don't hesitate it's worth a visit. The view there is also really nice.
Not very special but it was fine. The view was very nice and the free tea and a good price for the cake.

At first glance, the place looks nice except that the factory tour costs 500 RPS, If you want to see the tea fields and pick a little you will need to add 1000 rps Then if you want to taste a tea even a little to know what you are buying you will have to add 1100 rps All done in a clearly expeditious manner, Visit to the factory (20 mins), For the collection, we give you a bag, we tell you: you go there, you pick it up, you have 20 minutes and I will come back to pick you up! The store... No possibility of buying an individual box, there are only packs of 6 for the price of 6500 rps... No authenticity... Disappointed!!!
This is a great place to go with kids. They have tea factory tour.u need to pay for that.But it’s worth for the cost and affordable.

Poor service, we waited 20 min at the door for someone to even speak to us about a tour. The “tour” we did was tea plucking, she told us what leaves were picked in less than 1 minute and then we plucked a few and left. It was not at all a good experience. Yesterday we went to labookalie and it was a MUCH better experience.

They give an educational tour in the  tea factory. About how the tea is being manufactured and types of tea. This is very good for adults  as well as  kids. They charge Rs. 100 per person ( for  locals). After the tour you will be given a warm cup of tea, free of charge. If you want you can by tea from their sales outlet.

We enjoyed our tour of the factory although our guide was a quietly spoken girl. Afterwards, we were given a cup of tea in a pleasant little restaurant. Very nice. Takes about 15-20 minutes to do the tour.
Worth a visit and the guide answered all the questions although I do not know why photos were not allowed to be taken. No pressure was put on us to buy the tea.
Since we arrived together with the westerner groups we, can see the favoritism in entertaining guests by the staff.

We went on a Sunday so no picking or processing happening but lovely staff showed us around .Certainly puts a different perspective on a simple cup of tea ! Such hard physical work for the ladies picking . Great tea samples after the tour.

This very old original tea estate offers tours to visitors of the main factory during the day as the tea is actually made at night when it is cooler. Clear explanations of the various levels of tea and a beautiful cup of tea at the end. Stunning location close to town.
An hour well spent on an introduction into how the Tea Leaf is made into Tea. From plant to the finished product. Well worth a visit

I don't think it's worth it, but it is just 200 roepies. You will guided through the trees factory, she will tell something about the price of producing tea. But her English is not really good, it's a script. You can't understand it, it think Google helps you more about the proces.

Review Title: Not worth the money at all
Review Text: Extremely Disappointed – Not Worth the Money! Pedro Tea Factory is an absolute rip-off! They charge 1000 rupees just for a basic factory visit – no complimentary tea, no plantation walk, nothing extra. That price is outrageous considering other tea factories in the area offer much better service and a more immersive experience for half the price or even free. On top of that, the staff were shockingly rude and unwelcoming. They clearly don’t care about tourists or customer service. It felt like we were an inconvenience to them. There are plenty of other tea factories in Nuwara Eliya that are far more worth your time and money. Don’t waste either of those at Pedro. Highly disappointing.

The tour guide from the tea factory has strong accent. It's very hard to understand what she said. The facilities inside the factory are good though. However, the souvenir shop was disappointing. Very few options and no price tag there. Also they use special names for different types of tea so even harder to know what types of tea they are. The only advantage is this tea factory is not too far. We have been to Bluefield tea garden and ceylon tea museum in Kandy. Those are much better places to buy tea in terms of varieties and prices.

It is worth a visit as you get to see inside the factory and are taken through the whole tea production process. Then you get a cup of tea to taste and it is delicious. The tour and tea are free and given with the usual lovely Sri Lankan smile!

A good tour, although rather quick (roughly 20-30 mins). We came on a Sunday so only one machine was working, and no tea picking - not to mention torrential rains. Our tour guide was really informative, giving us plenty of info although it would’ve been nice to hear about more about the founding of the estate and the fermentation process. But for 250lkr and a great cup of tea at the end (which we then purchased for a great price) it’s definitely worth the trip from Nuwara Eliya. The views are beautiful and I’m sure during the week when the pickers are out and the weather is more pleasant a stroll around the fields would be worth it. I’d recommend getting a list of questions you want to ask, as they’re happy to answer any questions if you find you haven’t had one answered.

Paid 200 LKR for the factory tour which the staff told us would take 20 minutes. The machines weren't operating during our visit and we were completely fine with it. The tour took only 10 minutes and the guide wasn't knowledgeable at all. Everyone who left good reviews must have gotten a different guide. When I asked questions, she seemed very annoyed and was just hurrying us to get out of the tea factory to quickly end the tour. The guide is a local woman who is quite short and skinny (if you must know to avoid her). After the tour, they will serve you a cup of tea and it took them 20 minutes and after asking multiple times to serve us our tea. Very bad experience overall! Teas on sale are overpriced too. Other travellers we met who visited blue fields said that was really nice so perhaps check that out instead of Pedro. Bluefields offer free tour too I think! Avoid Pedro at all cost!

Dropped by on the way from the Horton plains and weren't disappointed. A nice short tour in the plant with a cup of tea afterwards made the end of the day. One can crop the tea leaves as well but we were unlucky - it started to rain once we set off.

Pleasant enough guided tour although not so much to see unless you come after 11.30 when the first tea comes in from the fields. Photography not permitted! Why not? Management policy apparently. Seriously? What’s the secret. A visit to a tea plantation last year in Kerala was much more animated and entertaining because they made sure to have a small batch of tea being crushed, rolled and dried specially for the fee paying visitors. Tea shop not impressive but maybe they’re more interested in selling by the sack at market than by the packet to tourists. I missed opportunity alas

We were staying in Nuwara Eliya for a couple of days and wanted to visit a tea plantation and this was recommended by the hotel (Grand). We took a Tuk-tuk from the hotel and the driver waited for us while we did the tour (approx 45 minutes in total including time to drink and buy tea). Very informative tour with a chance to see production from start to end with a good tour guide who was keen to answer questions. Great selection of tea to buy with a good explanation of what you are buying. We brought lots back. This felt like a  much more local experience than the commercial plantation that we stopped at on our way out of Nuwara. So would definitely recommend this - local, less expensive and felt a bit more real.

We had a very interesting morning here, the tour was informative and not too long, the factory still using machinery from the 1950s which are works of art in themselves. From the tea factory it's a good walk to Lovers Leap waterfall where you can see tea pickers at work. It's an easy bus ride from Kandy.
Me my wife n daughter enjoyed this place. It was amazing to see the process and tea estate was very beautiful 👍🏻
Honestly we visited 2 tea factories and found this one the best . It was nice , the tour was really nicely done and the estates were soooo pretty and secluded. Totally worth the visit
Nice guided visit to understand the process of making tea. After the visit you can walk in the plantations. It would have been nice to have a tea tasting at the end, as the visit is not free.
Went here in the afternoon. No tour available. Shop is small, offers some tasting. Tea is quite nice actually. Not worth going out of your way to get her; if you are in the area, ok.

We visited, when on our tour through Sri Lanka passing by, this tea factory with its old machines, had tour and bought some tea. It is worth to have a visit here - as well as strolling through the plantations - on public ways of course. Nice and beautiful place.

The visit was very quick and hard to understand. Machines are not working during the visit because they work only in night time. They offer a very good cup of tea after the visit, and you can buy tea also but it's expensive. We preferred the visit of Dambatenne tea factory in Haputale.

A very good tea factory, working mainly in the night. The tour costs 200 rupees, but include a complimentary excellent cup of tea, and the plantation grounds are very well tended and magnificent to look at.

We arrived at the tea boutique just when a group started the factory tour. They told us the next tour would start in 20 minutes and asked us to take a walk around the tea plantation first. The view was truly amazing. After the walk, we went back to the tea boutique and waited. The group we saw earlier finished their tour and was given tea to drink. We continued to wait but nothing happened. Then a staff asked us if we wanted tea. We asked if the tour would start soon and was told that it would not start for another 15 minutes. We ended up waiting for around 40 minutes before the tour finally started. We were given aprons and shower caps to wear. The tour guide was soft-spoken and we could only hear part of the explanations. After the tour, we wanted to buy some tea to take home. There were many different types of teas and we had no idea about differences. When we asked the staff, she only gave us some half-hearted attention. It would have been better if they could put up signs next to the teas to explain the differences.
Well worth a visit as it provides a great insight into the tea making process through the guided tour. This was followed by some tea sampling. Pedro is an ethical tea producer so well worth a visit.

Since this tea factory was very close to our Nuwara Eliya hotel, we decided to take a tour.  It was a bit disorganized at the beginning, as we purchased our ticket and were then told to sit in a waiting area.  Meanwhile, we saw people gathering and being handed aprons, and turns out this was our group, but no one told us.  So we joined in and had an informative walk through the factory.  Most of the work is done at night, as the tea picked during the day has to dry, so only a couple of machines were actually running.  No problem, and they were nice enough to let us know this when we purchased the tour ticket. Our favorite part was the cup of tea provided at the end.  We enjoyed sitting outside on the balcony with a lovely view of the plantation.  We hope you enjoy the tour as much as we did!

Thanks to our guide who was knowledgeable we left with a good understanding of the Tea Making process.  The factory is clean, staff are helpful and efficient and the complementary Tea is fabulous! 200 rupees and the best tour we did!

An enjoyable guided tour around an authentic tea factory. All the equipment is on display and the guide explains what its used for, though what is operating depends on the time of day.
